title: California Homestead Exemption: Motorized RV
question: Can a motorized RV be claimed as exempt under the California homestead laws if I live in it? I am in sales and sometimes need to travel within California so I do drive it around as needed when I go places but it is my residence. Can the trustee challenge my exemption?
question_tags: Child support,Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy homestead exemption,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,State, local, and municipal law,Representing yourself
answers: If the RV is deemed to be a vehicle by the DMV, then your exemption would be under CCP 703. The maximum exemption(s) under this code is $28,225, The homestead exemptions of CCP 704, which vary from $75,000 to $175,000, are for residences; residential homes, mobile homes that are fixed to the land, like in a trailer park. I strongly urge you to consult with a lawyer, who would need details before a definite answer could be given you. The more information you provide, the better answer you will be given.

First, no attorney can really advise you if it is exempt or not ! Why? Because we don't know if you have lived in CA more than the last 2 years . If not, another state's law will govern unless you also lived in CA before the 2 year rule also possibly depending on how long!

Second, assuming you did live in CA more than 2 years, you have an excellent CA attorney who have seen many great answers throughout the last 2 years showing his superb knowledge. Find one in CA now. But other facts and issues can also affect your case so I will point those out next for you too.

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an
attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping
everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the
exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523
(Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and
presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so
you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!
Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your
state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but
your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity
thereof!
Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your
options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you
have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply
with your attorney too.
But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a
relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that
relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the
bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so
meet with one no matter what.
Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one
as soon as you can.
You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now
and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

You have an RV with equity? Most people I seen are underwater on their RV. It is my understanding the California exemptions not used for a homestead can also be applied towards any other property as a "wildcard." Thus, the exemption law provides for another form of protection if the homestead does not apply. But to use California exemptions, you have to have lived in California for more than 2 years. Don't be crossing state lines to register your RV elsewhere to obtain lower taxes or insurance rates! Hope this perspective helps!

The trustee can challenge anything, but that does not mean that the trustee will prevail. Mr. Steingraber knows bankruptcy and California law. If he says you can claim the exemption under the conditions stated, if you meet those conditions you are fine.

If you file in California, you live in one of the few states that gives you two exemption schemes under state law, but you can only choose one or the other. This is just one of the reasons why filing with the assistance of an experienced bankruptcy attorney is important. Another is the fact that per a report issued by the US Courts in 2011, the survey that was performed found that pro se chapter 7 cases were dismissed 8 times as often as chapter 7 cases that were filed with attorney representation. The study also found that attorney represented chapter 13 cases result in a confirmed play 55 times more often that pro se chapter 13 cases.

An experienced bankruptcy attorney that practices before the judge and trustee that will be assigned to your filing will know how these matters are handled and what you need to do to protect your assets and will also understand other issues such as the timing of the filing of your case.

We see pro se bankruptcy filers on this forum every week that are asking questions about how to extricate themselves from the mess that they are in. Some are about to lose some of their assets or spend a substantial amount of money to correct the problem because they did something wrong or failed to understand why the asset would be taken by the chapter 7 trustee. Many times those filers are going to spend much more than those debtors would have paid a lawyer to do thing right the first time.

You can search for an attorney using the Avvo "Find a Lawyer" link at the top of this page. Many California attorneys like Mr. Steingraber will provide you with a free initial appointment.

If the RV is your primary residence and you do not have a "brick and mortar" home you need to exempt, you can claim an exemption for the RV. Don't file bankruptcy w/o first talking with several bk lawyers on Avvo.
